text.value: The phrase “His state is kingly” can be read as an expression of God’s majesty and authority. But the word “kingly” is problematic in the context of Milton’s political life, particularly at the time of the sonnet’s composition in early-to-mid 1650s. This task helps you find out why. Use your judgement to interpret the descriptions incorrectly listed in the right hand column, then align them with the correct dates in the left hand column.

value.value: Educated at St Paul’s School and Christ’s College Cambridge
As a young man, travels for a year in France and Italy
Two years before the Civil Wars, he begins writing tracts for Puritan  and Parliamentary causes
Outbreak of the English Civil Wars (finally concluding, 1651)
During the first phase of the Civil Wars, around 1644, Milton begins  to lose his sight
Commonwealth (Republican) Government lasts for more than a decade, ending two years after Oliver Cromwell’s death
Appointed Secretary for Foreign Tongues, serving until 1660
Within a few months of his appointment, publishes Eikonoklastes,  his defence of the execution
Around this time, by now completely blind, Milton composes ‘When  I consider how my light is spent’
Composition of Paradise Lost, first published in 1667
Coronation of Charles II – the Restoration of the Monarchy

text.value: Charles II was crowned eleven years and three months after his father was executed.
